Great job as usual, but there's even more exciting stuff that wasn't covered. The ground penetrating radar, the weather station, laser beams, X-Ray and UV spectrometers (a first on Mars). Also, Moxie, as exciting as it is, isn't the only pre-human experiment. They have a bunch (I think 4-5) samples of potential space suit and visor materials. Unlike all previous missions, Perseverance will attempt to achieve 3 things: 1) Try to find evidence of ancient life (best chance we've ever had which is why I'm most excited), 2) With Moxie, space suit and visor material experiments, pave the way for human life on Mars, 3) Bring Mars to life for the general population with the most advanced cameras ever on Mars, aerial drone footage and sound for the first time!

10:37 for me what's weird is that the core samples ( at least going by artwork and other vids I've seen ) seem like they're just gonna be dropped off and left along in the rovers trail, like robot droppings. Wouldn't it make more sense to keep those samples all onboard so they can all be grabbed in one go? Plus with Mar's seasonal dust storms and all, seems like just dropping them along the path is begging for them to be lost or buried. If that's not how the samples will be handled then please ignore this.

As for why Perseverance takes the cores, but something else picking them up instead of making their own? Off the top of my head it seems that if Perseverance does all the drilling and sampling, then the power and space spent on that can be dedicated to retrieving those samples and returning them. No idea if that's the plan, just a thought off the top of my head ( and yeah, commenting and watching now while waiting for this sucker to get down to the surface )

I am not excited by MOxIE at all. It sounds stupid. If you want get hydrogen, it comes from water: you've made oxygen as a byproduct. If you want metal, it comes from rock: you've made oxygen as a byproduct. If you want carbon, it comes from CO2: you've made oxygen as a byproduct. If you want any of the vast array of materials that we manufacture from petrochemicals on Earth, you start by getting the carbon and hydrogen: you've made oxygen as a byproduct twice.

When the first Martians get out of their Starships, there will have to be a lot of stuff waiting for them, made by machines that were sent two years before. MOxIE is not an early prototype for any of those machines. It makes pure waste and throws away the good stuff. The mass could have been used for something with scientific value, like a telescope that would have given the rover a better view of the surrounding terrain, or a seismometer that would have been left at the landing site gathering data about the interior of Mars.

I'd challenge the idea that we need to make methane on Mars in order to be able to return to Earth. Methane can of course be imported to Mars, either as liquid methane directly or indirectly in the form of liquid ammonia (this also has the benefit of importation of nitrogen - which will be needed in quantity for life support). The argument that we can create methane locally, from mining/harvesting water ignores the fact that this will involve large scale mining/extraction and processing and all of this has to be imported from Earth. There is little to be gained in doing this. In the end, direct importation of methane or ammonia is likely to be the least complex and therefore least risky approach. Also direct return from Mars (aka Elon's Starship) requires industrial scale activity. Strip mining of large quantities of soil, industrial scale machinery and of course mega-scale power supplies. All of which has to be imported to Mars in the first place. This should be considered highly impractical for realistic near to medium term missions.

So why not bring the same drill and sample storage mechanism again?

1) Well because you'd need to bring another rover again! When you take rock samples on earth, it isnt just taking the sample. You have to take images, geo-locate it, and store it in containers. That takes a lot of mass and warrants a specialized rover. A smaller rover which just has to pick up a sample container just has to do that and nothing else! Landing a sample return rocket and a Perserverence 2 would be even harder because of an increase in mass but a small fetch rover and rocket is more tractable. We might as well send another Perseverance to do the whole thing in advance.

2) Perseverance is going far in advance of any other craft and can take advantage of a time delay because we haven't build Mars Sample Return yet and it takes time to wander about and capture a large area.

3) Perseverance will be able to expand a sample range! Because it has more time and more power than the fetch rover, it can cover a large area!

4) Its also good to handoff because we dont know what Mars Sample Return looks like yet. In order to load the samples, we'd need a robotic arm to do so, but its hard to design a robotic arm or loading system without knowing what it does. The Fetch rover acts as an interface that can both pick up the samples and hand it off appropriately because its designed in conjunction with the sample return module.

Everyday Astronaut
If you take an air pump and pressurize a greenhouse space on Mars with Mars's own atmospheric gasses to 1 earth atmosphere and grow a plant in the greenhouse you will get oxygen separation from the Mars high C-O2 atmosphere.
Granted the greenhouse would end up with quite a large percentage of those trace gasses along with the O2 but that will be a good starting point for additional scrubbing or processing and certainly a good way to slowly begin filling a space with usable gas rather than the future astronauts having to carry all there own.
In one theoretical design the tubes to any Mars habs that connect to one another would be perfect for this with a small section having enough window space for light with mirror assistance where needed to get enough concentrated light for photosynthesis to have the one or few plants start the slow process of removing the CO2 from the hallways.
Bear in mind the hallways will be sealed off from the two habs it will connect for the time being slowly building up pressure and O2 concentration.
Then an additional scrubber can remove the trace gasses and pump the O2 into the habs holding tanks and emptying the connection tube.
Then the connection tube can be refilled with gas from outside once again to restart the process.
Once all the habs O2 tanks and interiors are filled to capacity, you have a pair of habs and a connection corridor filled with O2 and ready to go.

When it comes to Mars rovers, NASA has behaved like a bunch of pikers held in thrall by the geologists (led by Steve Squyres). We never needed to be told, because we already knew, that Mars used to have loads of water and a thicker atmosphere. These simple facts can be adduced from the most cursory of observations - and already were.

What we paid NASA to do was to go out and look for signs of life, both past and present. And they always played along, dangling that carrot as if that was what their missions were all about. But bollocks they were.

They got off to a good start with the Viking missions. They took along a little laboratory capable of rudimentary analysis of organics, and tantalising results were immediately returned. But after that, the geologists moved in and everything turned to schist for decades.
